abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, yet, institutional
            development impacts were only modest. Lessons first indicate
            that the strategy to have investors own, and run the
            Palestine Mortgage and Housing Corporation (PMHC), while
            having commercial banks as retailers, did correctly allocate
            the risks. However, the project could have benefited from a
            more nuanced understanding of the impediments that private
            actors faced, and might have devised efficient strategies to
            address them. For this project, those issues included
            property registration, laws and regulations concerning the
            pledging of property, and the entire regulatory environment
            for the mortgage business. However, actual reforms would not
            likely have been successful without the imminent prospect of
            real loans waiting to be made. Likewise, projects with
            private entities at their core, should be structured,
            recognizing that neither the Bank and nor the borrower can
            control the pace of implementation. A second lesson
            addresses how to maximize the synergy among Bank operations,
            for on a subject as broad as housing policy, there is a
            great need for a coordinated message, not only to the
            Housing Ministry, but to Finance, the Central Bank, the
            Planning Ministry, the Local Government Ministry, the
            Justice Ministry and more. Although the Bank had operations
            and dialogue with all of these parties, there was no
            mechanism to coordinate or integrate advice for improving
            project outcomes. This is probably a significant missed
            opportunity that could have improved the pace, if not the
            quality of product implementation.
